dek: Every year the top high school basketball prospects get hyped up. How often do they pan out?
title: The Next Michael Jordan

intro.value: Remember NBA great Donnell Harvey? Neither do we. Despite being the number one high school prospect in 2000—something that you think would indicate future NBA stardom—he put together a meager career in the league, averaging around 5 points per game over 5 years. On the flip side is LeBron James—the number one high school prospect just a few years later—now the *greatest NBA player of all-time.
This got us thinking, do we really know in high school how these players will turn out, or is it all just hype?

Hype is even more inflated now in the YouTube era. Sure, LeBron had some nationally televised games, but now millions of people are watching Zion Williamson throw down dunks in warm ups, or Lamelo Ball hit threes from half court in eight grade.
Let’s take a look at just how far the high school stars of the past 20 years made it in their basketball careers.
Below, each circle represents a single player that ranked amongst the Top 100 high school players in the US.

rankTitle: Level Reached of Top 100 High School Players
rankSub: Percentage of players that reach each level (out of 1,563 players) from 1998 - 2013
top10: Looks like only about 26% of the 1,563 top ranked high school players made it to the NBA and only 26% made it past their two-year rookie contract. A slim 5 players—LeBron James, Chris Paul, James Harden, Kevin Durant, and Kawhi Leonard—eventually reached an average vorp score of 4 or higher, claiming “Superstar” status. But perhaps the top 100 is too broad of a categorization. Surely the top 10 players will make it to the NBA more often, right?
top10Title: Level Reached of Top 10 High School Players
top10Sub: Percentage of players that reach each level (out of 158 players) from 1998 - 2013
postTop10: Players ranked in the top 10 certainly appear to have slightly better odds—a full 80% of them were eventually drafted to the NBA. In the late 90’s and early 2000’s, teams could bet hard enough on a player’s future success that they could draft them straight out of high school. This ended in 2006 when a rule was put into place, declaring that players had to be at least 19 years old or one year removed from high school before getting drafted. But since there are talks about reversing this rule as early as 2021, let’s look at the success of the straight-to-NBA high school players.
skipTitle: Level Reached of Straight-to-NBA HS Players
skipSub: Percentage of players that reach each level (out of 35 players) from 1998 - 2005

postSkip.value: Opponents of removing the age limit often cite players like Korleone Young as reasons to keep it in place. Young, the #3 ranked high school player in 1998, ultimately fizzled out of the NBA having played only 15 minutes across 3 games. However, he appears to be the exception more than the rule. Of the other 34 players drafted straight out of high school, 94% made it past their rookie contract, with 74% eventually becoming mediocre NBA players.

Let’s switch our view once more, away from the highest ranking high school players to those that played in a US high school, but never made it onto the Top 100 list. We found 338 of these players that were eventually drafted into the NBA, despite the tepid high school start. Let’s compare their career paths with our highly-ranked and drafted high schoolers.

allTitle: Level Reached of Drafted Top & Unranked HS Players
allSub: Percentage of players that reach each level (out of 779 players) from 1998 - 2013
postAll: Even when we limit the top ranked players to just those that were eventually drafted, the success rate of players ranked in high school is notably higher than for those who weren’t. Where 92% of the drafted and ranked players made it past their rookie contract, only 73% of the unranked and drafted players stayed more than 2 years. Three players, Russell Westbrook, Stephen Curry and Damian Lillard, whose high school careers were apparently not worthy of a spot amongst the top 100, still broke into the ranks of “AllStars” in their NBA careers.
college: Something about how these are the top schools and looking at players who go through these schools is cool.

big4Sub: Percentage of players that reach each level (out of 157 players) from 1998 - 2013
